Out of curiosity I took a swab of my 🍆 and put it in a jar of sugar water and yeast nutrients... It started fermenting and smelt like bread yeast. I did a few washes to separate out the yeast from any bacteria and I've just started a 1L wine experiment, it's currently at 5.5% alcohol and in my taste test it tastes like a good cider, the sugar in the grape juice is enough to get upto 9.5%... I didn't add any extra sugar in case the yeast strain I've managed to grow isn't tolerant to higher alcohol levels, most yeasts can get to at least 10% alcohol though (like baking yeast) so fingers crossed it doesn't end with too much left over sugars.

My only worry is that since it's a human borne yeast strain will it cause health problems like thrust if drunk unsterilised? I don't usually use potassium sorbate in my wine making as it blocks any bacteria that help age a wine (malo-lactic bacteria). If I can get it over 10% it should significantly reduce the risk of acetic bacteria forming in the wine and creating acetic acid (vinegar).

Please be careful and consider more in-depth and up-to-date fact checking.

Thinner people typically are MORE sensitive to insulin. Insulin sensitivity is the cause of diabetes, i.e. the less sensitive you are, the more insulin your body produces, which further decreases sensitivity, which further reduces cellular sensitivity and on and on.
The GREATER your insulin sensitivity, the less you produces. Therefore, having a diet that keeps insulin production low, protects your cells. They only get the insulin they need to push nutrients into them, without constantly overwhelming them. The lower your insulin, the less you weigh, the healthier you are. Unless your pancreas stops producing it, them you have to take it. Low glycemic diets protect your pancreas as well, as you aren't overtasking it, burning it out.

Although most of your body serotonine is maybe produced in your gut, your nervoussystem is protected by the bloodbrain barrier. This blocks serotonine, dopamine, glutamine, norepinephrine, epinephrine and other substances from entering your nervous system and thus your brian. With this, excessive amount of neurotransmitters are also actively pumped out of your nervous system. So the argument that your microbe influences your "mind" is not valid, they can produce neurotransmitters but these cannot enter our brain!

For the love of...*sigh* Autism. Is. Not. A. Disease. (I’m autistic - people like me are in the neurological minority, and sometimes have a lot of struggles due to this or issues that often accompany being autistic, but we are not seriously or even not-so-seriously diseased. We get enough of that crap from Autism $peaks & similar organizations. And your videos are awesome, and watched by millions of subscribers & other viewers...but that also means that millions of people just heard (again!) this idea that to be autistic is to be diseased/defective/damaged/broken/lost/MSSNG/“a puzzle”/a plague/crisis/tsunami/etc/etc/etc.

(And please don’t bring functioning labels in if you respond to this comment. The autistic community includes all autistics, no matter how much support they need or don’t need, & they can all speak for themselves if given the opportunity to communicate in their preferred method. And autistic self-advocates are pretty dang unified so far as this goes. There are exceptions to every rule, but I feel it’s safe to say any autistic who doesn’t struggle with internalized ableism would respond vehemently if someone said they “had a serious disease.”)

ASAN (the Autistic Self-Advocacy Network) is a great resource, btw, for any autistics or allies looking for more information. :)

This was put up on on October 5, but is outdated. Years ago they found that the womb is not sterile, and babies are exposed to bacteria and viruses from conception on, long before the baby is born. They figured this out with rapid gene array technology that looked at DNA, rather than trying to culture bacteria and viruses. What they found was that there were a lot more species of bacteria and viruses than were previously known, and that they are everywhere, including in areas of our bodies that used to be thought of as sterile, such as internal organs including the brain. So this video is already years out of date.

Pardon me, but autism isn't a disease. It's a developmental disablity, and nothing is inherently wrong with it. It just causes people to operate on a different system- it's a disability because society is geared towards helping out and supporting neurological people and not so much autistic people. Many autistic people learn coping mechanisms to deal with this- someone who is nonverbal might pick up sign language or someone who stims in a destructive way might learn to use some more healthy ones. But it isn't a disease, and you'd do well to remember that. I know you probably didn't mean to be insensitive, but I'm just letting you know.

Leaky Gut Syndrome is an interesting problem, where the bacteria don't process common food substances properly and create toxic byproducts which include psuedo-morphins that act on the brain causing swelling and cognitive problems.

This seems like the next step in medicine, if you think about it. Maybe, and hopefully, a way to get rid of antibiotics entirely. We already know that antibiotics are failing because we're relying too heavily upon them. Sure, it kills bad bacteria, but natural selection is at work, killing the weak bacteria, while the strong bacteria survive, becoming immune to each new iteration of antibiotic that needs to be made, until eventually we'll have super bugs that are immune entirely.

Antibiotics are, of course, non organic. It can't evolve or adapt, it needs us to keep making newer and more effective versions. Maybe we'll be able to get microbes to fight the bad bacteria. Unlike medicine, it won't simply go away. It'll be in our system, breeding continually as all organisms do, fighting bacteria. If the weak microbes die, the strong microbes that survive will pass on how to defeat bacteria, and rid it from our systems every time it tries to invade. If a new, stronger form of the bacteria comes along, again... weak microbes die, strong microbes survive, they pass that information on

It'll be anti-bacteria, and eventually through human procreation, we too will pass it to our children, eliminating the need to vaccinate or otherwise implant the bacteria-killing microbes.

This thought was spurred on because I knew about planting good poop microbes into other people who's gut flora was way off, but I had no idea it could be used to fight c difficile. It's what caused my grandfather to pass away earlier this year. He contracted it I think two or three times while in hospital, and each time he was given antibiotics, but I think they were failing him due to what I explained above, the fatal flaw of antibiotics. I wonder if he would still be alive if he had a fecal transplant instead of antibiotics... honestly, I couldn't say either way. He also had Alzheimer's, and it was pretty far along, and who knows what else may have contributed to his death. I wish he were alive, but in a way I'm glad he did not have to live as a shell of his former self.

Pardon, the autism part got me. Everything else, fairly fine, even the poop injections. It's just that when you have people around you from your background constantly shaming you for something you can't really change, be it your condition or the byproducts result from that condition, it really becomes personal when that long-time aspect of you is labelled a disease, and with it, created with great negativity. Such labels, when applied to certain aspects of yourself, carry with them implications of hostility when you carry unpleasant memories associated with your condition. It has inhibited my capacity for humor, rationality, and overall sociability, and denied any opportunity for me to be much more than I am because of the fear and regret it has created.

As nice as it'd be to ask for a helping hand, I fear it is too late. Any help would just be perceived as another act of hostility towards the sense of self I have created as a result of my condition, or exploitation of my potential ability should I actually benefit. The only help I'd ever truly accept is the opportunity to be alone and live in peace with myself, given time to find strength within my own limitations.

Saying that gut bacteria causes autism is oversimplifying things.
First of all, autism is not a disease and with early intervention many people with it can live happy lives even if they're a bit odd. Secondly, there's also strong evidence to support the theory that autism is a result of the brain being wired differently from birth. Gut bacteria can exacerbate some problems which is why some people with autism need to watch their diets, but not every person with autism has the same ecosystem. I'm on the spectrum and changing my diet has never helped me.

I guess that explains why I automatically switched to eating healthy weeks after I started living more actively. I wouldn't feel well if I only ate meat or starchy food. I would naturally crave leafy vegetables and then feel great afterwards.

To everyone saying Autism isn't a disease in the comments. It is. Look up the word disease.

In a standard dictionary:

dis·ease
dəˈzēz/
noun
noun: disease; plural noun: diseases; noun: dis-ease; plural noun: dis-eases

a disorder of structure or function in a human, animal, or plant, especially one that produces specific signs or symptoms or that affects a specific location and is not simply a direct result of physical injury.

In a Medical Dictionary:

dis·ease
dəˈzēz/
noun
noun: disease; plural noun: diseases; noun: dis-ease; plural noun: dis-eases

1 a condition of abnormal vital function involving any structure, part, or system of an organism. 2 a specific illness or disorder characterized by a recognizable set of signs and symptoms attributable to heredity, infection, diet, or environment.

Autism is a disease. It is in fact the thing this word is describing. As an autistic person, it bothers the shit out of me that you guys don't use words correctly. Please read the dictionary and use the proper words to convay your thoughts so we can all understand each other without having to resort to that context clue voodoo.

6:50 - "made them less sensitive to insulin"

It made them MORE sensitive to insulin. You want to be sensitive to insulin. Insulin signals your cells to start storing energy from sugar that is now in your blood, so it keeps blood sugar at a normal level. If your cells are not sensitive to insulin, they cant keep blood sugar stable and you are also more hungry. Beta cells in pancreas then up the production of insulin so you have both high insulin levels in blood and high blood sugar.

Insulin resistance makes you is what contributes to obesity and causes type 2 diabetes. Insulin sensitivity raises with dietary change and weightloss.

1:00 Oh boy, when I have correct you guys, I know today is going to be special. Asthma has nothing to do with natural birth vs C-Section itself, but the average size of a baby born via C-Section vs the average size of a baby born naturally. Larger babies have more fat resting on their lungs, which restricts their breathing, they often don't fit down the birth canal and must be removed via C-section, since forcing it may cause the child permanent damage during the process. Meanwhile babies of the average size statistically don't tend to develop Asthma regardless of being born naturally or via C-Section.

Also, there is little evidence to suggest that what you eat is self-perpetuated by your gut bacteria, to provide this you would have to show a mechanism of communication between the upgrow of certain bacteria and your hunger/craving response center in the brain. Overall great video just wanted to clear some misinformation up.

Help your gut, the environment and the creatures who are trapped for their entire lives in misery - go vegan! Veganuary is an excellent resource for support, recipes and more information.

Watch 'cowspiracy' for environmental issues, 'what the health' for minimising disease, 'carnage' for some comic relief, and 'earthlings' for a glimpse of how bad things really are for the poor animals we forcibly breed for us to use and consume. You can pick holes in all of those documentaries (apart from Carnage which isn't technically a documentary) - but each has a good portion of truth, and together, they paint a fairly full picture. From there you can do more research, but it's a good starting point.

Try it - even just for a week - the only regret most vegans have is not doing it sooner.

Much of this video is likely to be partially wrong or even fully wrong. The only claim that we can take with fair certainty is that bacteria have a role in the production of diverse chemicals in our body that affect us in a variety of ways. All the more specific aspects about how and in what way that happens don't seem to be well understood yet. It's critical that the chemical properties and changes in our bodies be the focus of studies if we want to understand how bacteria and our bodies change in different circumstances. I hope not too many people are mislead by the click-bait title and claims of this video and end up believing that this is all already hard proven science, cause it isn't.

The choices that a person makes over many years influence their health? WHO KNEW! Seriously I get that we're able to understand the inner workings better and better, but there is no magic pill (Well until there actually is a pill that literally contains the magic of nanotechnology that make us cybernetic at a nanoscopic level, but we're still centuries from that technology...black goo...heh)

I guess what I'm saying is, if you're unhealthy, you have it within your control to do something about it, we're not at the level of technological sophistication to retro-virally cure diseases in adult humans, but with the CRISPR tests we can indeed cure genetic issues in the zygotic phase of life, which is amazing that the cell line has the capability to use CRISPR to auto-edit faulty genetic sequences (think recessive gene diseases)

Once we really get going with genetic technology, well the idea of sharing the planet with races that have literally come about through humans choosing to modify genetics a la Dr. Moreau might frighten some, but the reality is we will eventually choose, not tomorrow, not next year, but eventually humanity will change.

One of the really interesting ones they didn't talk about are helminths (multicellular organisms in our gut; think gut worms) that release chemicals that stop themselves from being killed by the immune system. In doing this, they also prevent allergic disease. Some believe that the reason people in "developed" countries are more likely to get allergies is because we take anti-helminth medication to expel them from our bodies. In "developing" nations where people are more likely to have helminths, people are much less likely to have allergies (about 1/3 of the world's population is infected by helminths and MOST of them lead symptomless healthy lives).  I know what you're thinking "correlation does not equal causality" but studies done involving the removal of helminths have found that children in developing countries  often don't develop allergies until after they've had helminths removed from their bodies (sounds pretty causal to me). Obviously helminths can cause their own diseases if they get out of control (or if its a particularly pathogenic one) but everything in moderation right?

I minor nitpick: at 6:48 you say that the people who had stool transplanted from thin people had a decreased insulin sensitivity, which you stated to be what happens when you lose weight. However to my knowledge, people who are overweight tend to have lower insulin sensitivity (aka Insulin resistance), not thin people. This is why obese people have a higher risk of diabetes, their pancreas needs to produce higher amounts of insulin due to them NOT being sensitive to insulin, and it eventually tires the pancreas out. Ah, that's a great explanation for why trying new foods can disagree with you at first, but that you get a taste for it if you keep eating it. I guess that would explain my negative first experience having avocados.

I didn't get to try avocados until I was in my mid twenties when it came as a side on a meal, and the first time it really upset my GI tract. I didn't really care for the taste that much so whenever I ordered that main dish I would just have a nibble of the avocado, but over time I noticed that it stopped messing with my digestion and I actually began to grow fond of the taste and texture. I suppose that when you try a new food you run the risk of it not appealing to the gut bacteria that you have at the time, and that, on the other hand, you can luck out by already having gut bacteria which happens to be able to handle the new food if it's similar enough to something you typically eat (which originally cultivated that bacteria).

So, as long as the bacteria you already have happens to also be interested in whatever new food you're about to try, you'll be fine. Which makes me think: if you're a picky eater, it's probably in part due to a vicious cycle, because if you were to have a more diverse diet, your microbiome would be diverse as well, meaning more chances that you already have a kind of bacteria that's compatible with whatever you're about to try. I'd be interested in seeing this hypothesis tested.

Would a picky eater get GI distress more often than an adventurous eater when they're both trying new foods? Do picky eaters statistically have less GI stress if they're slowly introduced to new foods in smaller portions rather than binging on their first taste? I wonder if we could find out which foods have more bang for your buck, so to speak, by cultivating a set of bacteria that is as versatile as possible, so people prone to GI distress can have more jack-of-all-trades bacteria in their arsenal. I'd bet that people with GI distress more often than not have a great deal of unitasker bacteria.

I would like to argue that autism and schizophrenia are not diseases, but rather, mental disorders. I would also like to argue that a disease implies something that can be contracted and cured, which in the case of autism is simply not true

I would like to argue that, but I can't. "Mental disease" is used as a synonym for "mental disorder". I have nothing to support my case other than feelings, so let me just say that you are technically correct, but, as someone with autism, the way you put it is a bit hurtful. Why is autism not a disease then?
Simple. It is not "curable".
